resources.string: Up to 4% of all children in the world have conditions that will result in serious vision problems. Currently, over 38 million children are affected by an eye disease. However, 80% of serious cases can be reversed if detected at an early age.

Critical issues such as lazy eye, uneven vision, astigmatism and even cancer, can easily go unnoticed by parents and other adults, yet with early enough detection, treatment can almost always be successful and future vision loss can be avoided. Vision problems can affect a child’s academic performance in school (as well as their self-esteem). If children can get better vision care, they can increase their literacy. It has been estimated that” … a 1% rise in literacy scores translates into a 2.5% relative rise in labor productivity and a 1.5% increase in gross domestic product (GDP) per person” International Adult Literacy Survey Scores, Human Capital and Growth Across Fourteen OECD Countries (UofOttawa 2004). Today’s children must have necessary vision skills to perform successfully in school and in the workplace when they get older. When a population increases its literacy the economy becomes stronger.
- One out of every four children has a vision problem.
- 60% of students identified as problem learners in school have undetected vision problems.
- In the US, 48% of parents with children under 12 have never taken their child to an eye care professional.
- 80% of vision problem cases can be reversed if detected at an early age.
